unnormalised: My mother always dreamt big for us, her three children. Growing up in a small town in Bihar, resources were limited, but her ambition for our education was boundless. She envisioned us with prestigious titles, markers of success that would unlock doors and opportunities we couldn’t even fathom then. I remember her poring over newspaper articles, pointing out names with "Dr." or "Er." prefixes, whispering, "That's what you need to become, beta."
normalised: My mother always dreamt big for us, her three children. Growing up in a small town in Bihar, resources were limited, but her ambition for our education was boundless. She envisioned us with prestigious titles, markers of success that would unlock doors and opportunities we couldn’t even fathom then. I remember her poring over newspaper articles, pointing out names with "Doctor" or "Engineer" prefixes, whispering, "That's what you need to become, beta."

unnormalised: My elder brother, Rajiv, always had a knack for numbers. He secured admission to IIT Kanpur after a grueling year of preparation. It was a proud moment for the whole family. He graduated with a B.Tech (Hons.) degree in Computer Science, and Ma distributed sweets to the entire neighborhood. She framed his degree certificate and hung it prominently in our living room. The title "Er. Rajiv Kumar" became a badge of honor for her. He eventually pursued an MBA from IIM Ahmedabad, adding another feather to his cap. Seeing him with his "MBA" after his name, negotiating million-dollar deals, made her beam with pride.
normalised: My elder brother, Rajiv, always had a knack for numbers. He secured admission to I-I-T Kanpur after a grueling year of preparation. It was a proud moment for the whole family. He graduated with a B-Tech Honours degree in Computer Science, and Ma distributed sweets to the entire neighborhood. She framed his degree certificate and hung it prominently in our living room. The title "Engineer Rajiv Kumar" became a badge of honor for her. He eventually pursued an M-B-A from I-I-M Ahmedabad, adding another feather to his cap. Seeing him with his "M-B-A" after his name, negotiating million dollar deals, made her beam with pride.

unnormalised: My sister, Priya, on the other hand, excelled in the humanities. After scoring well in her Class 12 exams, she chose to study English Literature at Delhi University. Ma initially expressed concern. "Engineering and medicine are the only real degrees," she’d murmur. But Priya was passionate about writing and storytelling. She went on to complete her M.A. and then a Ph.D. in Literature. It took years of hard work and dedication, but when she finally earned the title "Dr. Priya Sharma," Ma’s eyes welled up. It wasn't the practical, money-making degree she had imagined, but she saw the joy and fulfillment in Priya's eyes and knew she had made the right choice.

She went on to complete her M-A and then a P-H-D in Literature. It took years of hard work and dedication, but when she finally earned the title "Doctor Priya Sharma," Ma’s eyes welled up. It wasn't the practical, money-making degree she had imagined, but she saw the joy and fulfillment in Priya's eyes and knew she had made the right choice.

unnormalised: My path was different. I wasn't academically inclined like my siblings. I struggled with exams and never felt the same drive to chase after degrees. After failing my 12th exams twice, I decided to pursue a diploma in photography from a local institute. Ma was disappointed, to say the least. "A diploma? What kind of 'title' is that?" she’d ask, her voice laced with concern. She kept suggesting I re-attempt the Class 12 exams or try for a polytechnic.

What kind of 'title' is that?" she’d ask, her voice laced with concern. She kept suggesting I re-attempt the Class twelve exams or try for a polytechnic.

unnormalised: However, photography was my passion. I started assisting a local photographer, learning the ropes, and honing my skills. I worked tirelessly, taking on small assignments and building my portfolio. Slowly but surely, I started getting recognition for my work. My photos were published in local magazines, and I even won a few awards.
normalised: However, photography was my passion. I started assisting a local photographer, learning the ropes, and honing my skills. I worked tirelessly, taking on small assignments and building my portfolio. Slowly but surely, I started getting recognition for my work. My photos were published in local magazines, and I even won a few awards.

unnormalised: One day, I received a call from a prestigious photography magazine offering me a full-time position. Ma was still skeptical, but when she saw the excitement in my eyes and the pride I took in my work, she started to understand. "So, you’re a… what do they call it… a 'professional photographer'?" she asked hesitantly.

"So, you’re a… what do they call it… a 'professional photographer'?" she asked hesitantly.

unnormalised: I nodded, smiling. "Yes, Ma. And I'm good at it." I realized that a formal degree wasn't the only path to success or a respectable title. My skill and dedication had earned me a different kind of recognition.
normalised: I nodded, smiling. "Yes, Ma. And I'm good at it." I realized that a formal degree wasn't the only path to success or a respectable title. My skill and dedication had earned me a different kind of recognition.

unnormalised: Later that year, I photographed a major event in our town. The local newspaper featured my photos prominently, crediting me as "Mr. Rohan Kumar, Professional Photographer." Ma proudly showed the newspaper to everyone she met. I overheard her telling her friends, "My son is a famous photographer now. He has a 'title' too, just like his brother and sister."

unnormalised: It dawned on me then that for Ma, the "titles" were never really about the degrees themselves. They were about the recognition, the respect, and the sense of pride they brought. They were a symbol of our hard work and our potential.
normalised: It dawned on me then that for Ma, the "titles" were never really about the degrees themselves. They were about the recognition, the respect, and the sense of pride they brought. They were a symbol of our hard work and our potential.

unnormalised: While "Dr." and "Er." held their own weight, "Mr. Rohan Kumar, Professional Photographer," was the title that truly mattered to me because it represented my journey, my passion, and my own unique path to success, a path my mother eventually came to understand and celebrate. And in her eyes, that was a title worth more than any degree.
